news.headline: Rising chip costs to push global smartphone shipments down in 2026, Counterpoint says
news.summary: Global smartphone shipments are expected to decline 2.1% next year as rising chip costs ​are likely to impact demand, technology-focused market research firm ‌Counterpoint said on Tuesday.  Electronics supply chains around the world have been hit ‌by a shortage of legacy memory chips in recent months as manufacturers turned their focus to high-end memory chips suited for semiconductors designed for AI applications.  What we are seeing now ⁠is the low end ‌of the market (below $200) being impacted most severely, with bill-of-materials costs (total cost of parts) increasing by ‍20% to 30% since the beginning of the year, Counterpoint's Research Director MS Hwang said.

news.headline: Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours to nearly round-the-clock
news.summary: STORY: :: FileThe Nasdaq is seeking to roll out near round-the-clock trading of stocks.The stock exchange is one of the world’s largest and home to tech heavyweights Nvidia, Apple and Amazon.It plans to file paperwork to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to expand trading hours from 16 hours a day to 23 hours a day, five days a week.Nasdaq’s plans would see its trading week kick off on Sunday at 9 p.m. Eastern and end Friday at 8 p.m.:: FileA trading day would be split into two sessions with an hour break at 8 p.m. for maintenance, then start back up at 9 p.m., and would still feature opening and closing bells.It follows plans announced both by the New York Stock Exchange and Cboe Global Markets for those exchanges to move to nonstop five-day-a-week trading.Investor demand for nonstop trading of U.S. stocks has surged in recent years.That’s led regulators to introduce new rules and allow proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond traditional market hours.Today the U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies around the globe……and foreign holdings of U.S. equities hit $17 trillion last year, according to Nasdaq data.Advocates for moving closer to 24/7 trading argue it will allow investors, especially those outside the U.S., to react more quickly to events that happen outside regular market hours.Major Wall Street banks are cautious about the push, pointing to anxiety over lower liquidity, more volatility, and uncertainty over returns on investment.

news.summary: Paramount Skydance Corp.’s hostile bid to snatch Warner Bros. Discovery Inc. from under the nose of Netflix Inc. encapsulates the themes that have shaped a banner year for mergers and acquisitions: renewed desire for transformative tie-ups, massive checks from Wall Street, the flow of Middle East money and US President Donald Trump’s role as both disruptor and dealmaker.  Global transaction values have risen around 40% to about $4.5 trillion this year, data compiled by Bloomberg show, as companies chase ultra-ambitious combinations, emboldened by friendlier regulators.  “There’s a sentiment in boardrooms and among CEOs that this is a potential multi-year window where it’s possible to dream big,” said Ben Wallace, co-head of Americas M&A at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. “We’re at the beginning of a rate-cutting cycle so there’s anticipation that there will be more liquidity.”

news.headline: Amazon and Google launch multicloud service for faster connectivity
news.summary: Amazon and Google introduced a jointly developed multicloud networking service on Sunday to meet growing demand for ​reliable connectivity the companies said in a statement, at a time when ‌even brief internet disruptions can cause major outages.  The new service is being unveiled a little over a month after an Amazon Web Services outage on October 20 disrupted thousands of websites worldwide, knocking offline some of the internet's most popular ⁠apps, including Snapchat and ‌Reddit.  The new offering combines AWS' Interconnect–multicloud with Google Cloud's Cross-Cloud Interconnect, to improve network interoperability, according to announcements by the two cloud providers.

news.headline: Nasdaq Seeks SEC Approval for 23-Hour Trading During Weekdays
news.summary: The firm asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to add an additional trading session, from 9 p.m. to 4 a.m. ET, according to a filing Monday.  “This evolution reflects a simple reality: global investors expect access on their terms, in their time zones, without compromising trust or market integrity,” Chuck Mack, senior vice president of North American markets at Nasdaq, said in an emailed statement.  The exchange joins peers in touting growing interest in trading US stocks outside of traditional market hours, which run from 9:30 a.m. ET to 4 p.m. Market participants outside US trading welcomed the potential for faster pricing on earnings and macroeconomic developments, though they cautioned that near-continuous trading would give investors less time to digest after-hours headlines and may lead to more extreme swings during hours when liquidity is thin.
